subject: English
objectives_bloom: Remember: Identify key vocabulary (owl, wise, night, forest).
Understand: Explain why the owl is called wise in simple terms.
Apply: Use the word 'wise' in a short sentence about self or family.
Analyze: Compare the owl's behaviour to another animal (e.g., rabbit).
Create: Invent a 1-2 sentence mini-story showing wisdom.
outcomes: By the end of the lesson, students will be able to retell the main idea of 'The Wise Owl' in simple sentences.
Pronounce 6 new vocabulary words with recognisable accuracy.
Demonstrate comprehension by answering 3 simple questions and completing a 3-step sequencing activity.
lesson_text_summary:
Summary (copyright-safe teaching text):

The Wise Owl lives in a quiet forest. Every night the owl sits on a high branch and watches the animals. The owl is called wise because it listens first, thinks carefully, and then helps the other animals by giving good advice. In the story, a rabbit worries about a lost path and the owl helps by asking questions and noticing small traces on the ground. The animals learn that listening and thinking calmly are important when solving problems.

Moral: Being wise means thinking carefully and listening before acting.

vocabulary.notes: A bird that is active at night.
Shows good thinking; makes good choices.
A large area with many trees and animals.
To pay attention to sounds or someone speaking.
A small sign that shows something happened.

ai_dialogue_flow.ollie: Hello, young explorers! I'm Ollie the Owl. Tonight we will meet a wise friend from the forest. Are you ready to flap your wings and learn?
Say the magic word with me: WISE. One, two, three — WISE! Great job.
Listen to these new words: owl, wise, forest, listen, advice. Repeat after me: OWL... WISE... FOREST...
Now I will read the story. Listen carefully. [read short paragraph 1]
Who sat on the high branch? Tap the right picture: Owl, Rabbit, or Dog?
Let's listen to the next part. [read short paragraph 2]
Time to put the pictures in the correct order. Drag picture A, B, C to make the story.
Now your turn — tell me in one sentence how the owl helped the rabbit.
You did great! You earned feathers of wisdom. Remember: listening first is part of being wise.

activities.title: Read-Along & Repeat
steps: Ollie narrates paragraph 1 with clear, slow TTS.
AI prompts student to repeat sentence-by-sentence.
ASR checks for presence of key words (owl, wise, forest) and gives gentle corrective feedback.
If student repeats correctly, award 5 XP.

activities.title: Picture Sequencing
steps: Show 3 illustrated scenes from story in shuffled order.
AI gives hint after one wrong attempt (highlight correct first scene).
Successful sequence awards badge 'Story Order' and 10 XP.

activities.title: Word-Picture Match
steps: Student matches each word to picture by drag or tap.
AI provides example sentence for missed words and a mini-practice.

activities.title: Retell in One Sentence
steps: AI prompts student: 'Tell me in one sentence how the owl helped the rabbit.'
ASR extracts keywords; AI checks for 2 of 3 key concepts (owl/listen/advice).
If criteria met, award 'Tiny Storyteller' badge and 20 XP.

activities.title: Moral Match & Draw
steps: Multiple choice: 'What is the story's lesson?' with options.
If student selects correct option, prompt them to draw or select a picture showing 'listening' or 'thinking'.
Upload saved drawing or choose in-app sticker to represent the moral. Award 10 XP.

gamified_flow.progression: Collect 3 feathers to unlock 'Reader Owl' badge.

quiz_items.q: Who sat on the high branch?
Why was the owl called wise?
Match the word to meaning: Wise -> ?
Tell one way the owl helped the rabbit (in one sentence).

asset_requirements: audio TTS files for Ollie (3 voice speeds)
